Sarah\u2019s light skin means she can pass as white but her brother cannot. Meanwhile, Nora\u2019s dark skin means she can pass as black but her daughter cannot. As a child, Sarah is repeatedly told that because she is light-skinned, she is special and not like the other \u2018darkies\u2019. Yet when she grows up, her skin colour is a barrier to her happiness and she has to pass as white to find a suitable husband. Meanwhile, Nora is also told that she is special because she is dark-skinned, yet she is poor and cannot marry the man she loves. Both women feel that they are somehow betraying their identities when they are forced to pass as something they are not. "),mdx("h2",null,"Passing and Authenticity"),mdx("p",null,"When Nora\u2019s son asks her if she is \u201Cas black as ","[she]"," can be\u201D, she replies, \u201CI\u2019m as black as I can afford to be!\u201D This line expresses both the idea that to be as authentic as possible is to be genuine, yet it also references the fact that we all make choices about what level of \u2018authenticity\u2019 we present ourselves with. Nora refuses to see Harry as an equal, despite the fact that he is a hard-working, intelligent man who shares many of her interests. She refuses to acknowledge that he has the right to pursue his passions, and feels that he is less of a person because of his \u2018lower-class\u2019 status.
